March 1922.SECRET.CP. 3849.- 8 CABINET.SPECIAL WEEKLY REPORT ON UNEMPLOYMENT.No. 61.WEEK ENDED MARCH 10, 1922 THE SITUATION. The prospects of immediate trade revival still appear remote. Although some slight improvement has been recorded in various industries, the lock-out in theengineering trades makes the position most uncertain. In coal-mining employment is slightly improved. The slight improvement inthe steel and iron industry has been maintained. In shipbuilding and engineering,so far as new work is concerned, there has been no development. Ship-repairing,however, remains fairly active in most centres. In the cotton industry the slight improvement recorded last week has becomerather more marked. In.the woollen industry the number of employees reabsorbedcontinues to increase. There has been a slight improvement in lace manufacture atNottingham. Employment in the hosiery trade remains good. In general engineering the position is entirely overshadowed by the lock-out.The building industry shows a slight improvement due to seasonal causes. Theimprovement in the pottery and china industry has been maintained. The positionin glass manufacture appears to be slightly worse. There has been some improve-ment in the wholesale clothing trade in certain areas. T. J. MACNAMARA, Ministry of Labour NOTE ON UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION IN UNITED KINGDOM ON MARCH 10, 1922. 1. The Trade Union figure of unemployment for July 1914 was 2-8 per cent. The average for the ten years prior to the war, according to Trade union unemployment figures, was 4-7 per cent. It was as high as 7-8 per cent, in 1908 and7-7 per cent, in 1909. During 1919 it ranged between 1-6 per cent, in September and 3-2 per cent, inDecember, and averaged 2-4 per cent, for the year. During 1920 it ranged between 0-9 per cent, in April and 6-0 per cent, inDecember, and averaged 2-4 per cent, for the year. The figures for 1921 were: To the end of- Per cent. Workpeople who are unable so to comply are excluded. I. SUMMARY OF ACTION TAKEN BY THE GOVERNMENT. [From Autumn 1920 to Autumn 1921.] Cabinet Unemployment Committee, The prospect of a severe trade depression first became evident in the early autumn of 1920. On the 13th August, 1920, there was a special discussion at a meetingof the Cabinet, when the Cabinet Unemployment Committee was appointed toconsider the whole question and devise means for relieving unemployment. [This Committee has since been in constant session and has, up to the. 10thMarch, 1922, held 42 meetings. The problem of unemployment in one form or another has also been before theCabinet on 58 occasions between the 13th August, 1920, .and the 10th March, 1922.] (A.) Unemployment Insurance. An Unemployment Insurance Bill of general scope wras passed into law on the9th August, 1920, and came into operation on the 8th November following. TheAct applied compulsory insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons ascompared with 4,000,000 previously. Subsequent amending Acts modified theconditions as regards rates of benefit and the amount thereof which could be drawn.Contributions were also increased and authority given to borrow monev from theTreasury up to 20,000,000.Table showing amount paid out in Unemployment Benefit and the contributions during the period November 8, 1920, to March 6, 1922. A full statement of the measures taken in the autumn of 1920 and of the latermeasures from autumn 1921 onwards has been set out in previous issues of thisReport.
